trial_identification.studytitle: The Effect of Intranasal Dexmedetomidine Premedication on the Minimum Alveolar Concentration of Sevoflurane for the Insertion of Laryngeal Mask Airway in children
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The Effect of Intranasal Dexmedetomidine Premedication on Reducing the Minimum Alveolar Concentration of Sevoflurane for the Insertion of Laryngeal Mask Airway in Children

conditions.healthcondition: Induction and maintenance of general anaesthesia in children

interventions.interventions: GroupD1 received 1mcg/Kg intranasal dexmedetomidine premedication 45min before general anaesthesia; GroupD2 received 2mcg/Kg intranasal dexmedetomidine premedication 45min before general anaesthesia;the intervention and the participants will be monitored throughout the duration of the procedure with follow up ending 4 hours after the procedure has been completed
interventions.comparator: Group P received intranasal saline premedication 45min before general anaesthesia;the intervention and the participants will be monitored throughout the duration of the procedure with follow up ending 4 hours after the procedure has been completed

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine and compare the Minimum Alveolar Concentration of sevoflurane for LMA insertion in children by using Dixon and Massey up and down method
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At or one minute after LMA insertion

secondaryOutcome.outcome: the incident of adverse events were recorded in each patient's diary/health record for the trial e.g.laryngospasm,gapping,cough
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Timepoint: during the period of Inhalation induction

secondaryOutcome.outcome: the incidence of emergence agitation was evauated by the Pediatric Anesthesia Emergence Delirium Scale (PAED)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Participants will be followed for duration of PACU stay,an expected average of 2h

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Parent Satisfaction was evauated by the VAS Scale(0-10)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: at the time of children discharge from PACU

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: ASA 1 and 2 patients of either gender of the age 3- 7 years undergoing elective strabismus surgery under general anaesthesia which can be performed with LMA insertion
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Exclusion criteria: airway malformations, clinical evidence of patients with difficult airway, asthma or any sign of upper respiratory tract infection.

trial_design.concealment: Children were randomly allocated to one of the three groups to receive premedication either placbo (Group S), dexmedetomidine 1microg/kg (Group D1), or dexmedetomidine 2microg/kg (Group D2) in a double-blinded fashion according to random list generated by a computer. Allocation was concealed by the method of sealed opaque envelopes .
trial_design.statisticalmethods: the sample size of 28 patients of every patients was base on an alfa=0.05,Beta=0.8

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: No.134 Dongjie Street, Fuzhou, Fujian, China, 350001

fundingsource.fundingaddress: No.134 Dongjie Street, Fuzhou, Fujian, China, 350001

secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: No.134 Dongjie Street, Fuzhou, Fujian, China, 350001

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Sevoflurane is widely employed for inhalational induction of general anaesthesia in children. There is increasing evidence that dexmedetomidine is an effective and safe sedative in children. Laryngeal mask airway is an useful device for pediatric anesthesia. The aim of the current study was to determine whether Intranasal dexmedetomidine premedication can reduce MAC of sevoflurane for an LMA insertion in children
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Intranasal dexmedetomidine premedication reduces minimum alveolar concentration of sevoflurane for laryngeal mask airway insertion and emergence delirium in children: a prospective, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial. Yao Y, Qian B, Lin Y, Wu W, Ye H, Chen Y. Paediatr Anaesth. 2015 May;25(5):492-8. doi: 10.1111/pan.12574. Epub 2014 Dec 8. PMID: 25487567
